week3.practice1_html:

week3.practice2_html:

week3.practice3_html:
What it is

Eat More Good Fats helps you raise your intake of omegaâ€‘3s â€” the antiâ€‘inflammatory fats that calm scalp inflammation, smooth hormone shifts, and feed the tiny oil glands that protect each strand.

Why this practice matters for you now

Ioanna, during stabilization your follicles are catching their breath after months of stress and hormonal waves. Low omegaâ€‘3s, combined with perimenopausal changes, can lengthen that lag. Adding the right fats now can quiet your scalpâ€™s stress signals and set up steady regrowth by next summer â€” this is your â€œbig dominoâ€ for moving from fragile to flourishing cycles.

Step-by-step implementation

  1. Upgrade two meals a week: Choose salmon, sardines, or mackerel, cooked gently (not deepâ€‘fried) to protect fats.
  2. Plant option: If fish isnâ€™t reliable, take an algaeâ€‘based omegaâ€‘3 supplement with both EPA and DHA; check expiry â€” rancid oil smells fishy or sharp.
  3. Balance your oils: Use olive or avocado oil for cooking and cut back on seed oils (sunflower, corn, soy) that crowd out omegaâ€‘3s.
  4. Pair with protein: Combine with lean protein (chicken, eggs, tofu) to give follicles both the building blocks and the â€œantiâ€‘inflammatory calm.â€
  5. Store well: Keep capsules or bottles in the fridge away from light and heat to prevent oxidation.

What to look for

  • Early wins: Within two weeks, itchiness or scalp tightness eases; skin feels less dry; energy after meals steadies.
